node.title: NZ exports to get greater access to Chinese market after FTA upgrade
node.description: New Zealand has ratified an upgrade to its 2008 free-trade agreement with China that will give exports greater access to the Chinese market.

node.description: The vessel is believed to have sunk after the hull became filled up with rainwater.

node.title: Meteorologist receives surprise Valentine's Day marriage proposal on air
node.description: While accepting the proposal, she expressed her desire to have a Northern Lights proposal, and in some ways, this wish came true.

node.title: L.A. man charged with trying to open plane door in midair
node.description: The Washington-D.C. bound flight was forced to land in Kansas City after the passenger was subdued.

node.title: Omicron: High demand for Covid-19 testing in Auckland causing delays
node.description: Lengthy queues are being reported at Covid-19 testing centres in Auckland for the second day in a row.

node.title: Amy Schumer among hosting trio for Oscars ceremony - reports
node.description: Comic actors Amy Schumer, Regina Hall and Wanda Sykes will host this year's Academy Awards ceremony, Variety and other media outlets are reporting.

node.title: Covid-19: Daily community case numbers drop to 744 from Monday's record high
node.description: There are 744 new community cases of Covid-19 being reported in New Zealand today.

node.title: Thousands still without power in North Island after Cyclone Dovi
node.description: Powerco still has more than 5000 customers without power due to outages caused by Cyclone Dovi.

node.title: Booster shot deadline communication 'appalling' - Disability Support Network
node.description: The Disability Support Network says the Ministry of Health's failure to notify the sector of a booster deadline extension could have resulted in staff being unnecessarily suspended or dismissed today.

node.title: Covid-19: Parliament press gallery journalist returns negative test
node.description: A journalist at Parliament's Press Gallery, who had a positive rapid antigen test for Covid-19 yesterday, has tested negative in a full PCR test.

node.title: Traveller self-isolation rules allow bubbles, require direct travel to accommodation
node.description: Travellers to New Zealand will be able to self-isolate in a bubble with family or friends, and will be able to leave isolation in specific circumstances, the government says.

node.title: Six charged over alleged corruption with subcontracts
node.description: Six people have been charged by the Serious Fraud Office for alleged corrupt behaviour involving road maintenance contracts in South Auckland.

node.title: Sir John Key to partner with Chow brothers in property development firm
node.description: Former Prime Minister Sir John Key and his son Max are joining up with property developers and one-time brothel owners, John and Michael Chow.

node.title: Couple accused in $4.5-billion bitcoin scheme to be split before trial
node.description: Ilya Lichtenstein is in jail, and wife Heather Morgan has been freed; the judge said evidence tying them to the scheme is "very strong."

node.title: Omicron response: 'We should have been at phase two last week'
node.description: The country should have moved to phase two of the Omicron response plan last week, to give GPs more time to prepare for dealing with the outbreak, Dr Rawiri Jansen says. Audio

node.title: Cook Islands detects first case of Covid-19
node.description: The person with coronavirus is a close contact of an Auckland case, and is isolating at their holiday accommodation, Prime Minister Mark Brown says.

node.title: Kaiapoi factory fire was accidental - investigators
node.description: The Sutton Tools factory in the north Canterbury town went up in flames last month, flushing about 3000 litres of oil into three nearby rivers.

node.title: 'A tricky situation': University 'waits it out' for solution to protest that closes campus
node.description: Victoria University of Wellington is backing the police's cautious approach to handling the protest that has closed its city campus and seen staff and students abused. Audio

node.title: Russia-Ukraine standoff: What you need to know now
node.description: The U.S. warns a Russian attack on Ukraine could come at "any time," but neither side has abandoned diplomacy yet.

node.title: Justin Trudeau invokes emergency powers to quell protests

node.title: Sadowski-Synnott cruises through Big Air qualifying
node.description: Snowboarder Zoi Sadowski-Synnott's quest for a second Winter Olympic Games gold medal is off to a smooth start.

node.title: Medical physicists to strike tomorrow after stalled pay negotiations with DHBs
node.description: The 48-hour full strike comes after 12 weeks of partial strike action, which has seen physicists refuse to operate machinery outside of ordinary hours.

node.title: An allergy-friendly cookie company finds sweet success after rejection
node.description: She started her business after finding out her daughter was allergic to corn during an emergency room visit.

node.title: Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, tests positive for Covid-19
node.description: The Duchess of Cornwall is self-isolating after testing positive for Covid-19, Clarence House has confirmed.

node.title: 'It's created a big mess": Farmers despair over ruined crops
node.description: Weeks of persistent rain have left arable crops sodden and led to farmers describing this season as the harvest from hell.

node.title: 'This is crazy': Shortfall in booster numbers worries top Covid-19 adviser
node.description: The one million New Zealanders who are so far delaying getting their booster shots are the biggest concern of top Covid-19 adviser Sir David Skegg. Audio

node.title: Father of Parkland victim climbs crane to call for action on gun violence

node.title: Chartered accountants intent on reducing $60K gender pay gap
node.description: A new playbook has been launched to combat the gender pay gap in the accounting sector, with efforts to change the perception around why it is important to address the gap.

node.title: Canada protest: Trudeau to invoke rarely used emergency powers - media
node.description: The Canadian Prime Minister will invoke rarely used special measures allowing him to tackle protests that have shut some border crossings and paralysed downtown Ottawa, local media reports say.
